original: Majjhima Nikāya 119
analyzed: majjhima nikāya
translated: Middle Length Discourses

original: Kāyagatāsatisutta
analyzed: kāyagata asati sutta
translated: Mindfulness of the Body

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: Once the Blessed One was staying at Sāvatthī, in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Park.

original: Atha kho sambahulānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṁ upaṭṭhānasālāyaṁ sannisinnānaṁ sannipatitānaṁ ayamantarākathā udapādi:🔽“acchariyaṁ, āvuso, abbhutaṁ, āvuso.
analyzed: atha kho sambahulānam bhikkhūnam pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkantānam upaṭṭhāna sālāyam sannisinnānam sannipatitānam ayam antarākathā udapādi  acchariyaḥ āvuso abbhutaḥ āvuso
translated: Then, after the meal, on returning from alms round, a number of monks assembled in the assembly hall and this discussion arose:

original: Yāvañcidaṁ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā vuttā mahānisaṁsā”ti.🔽Ayañca hidaṁ tesaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ antarākathā vippakatā hoti, atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamayaṁ
analyzed: yāvañcidam tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena kāya gatā asati bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā vuttā mahā nisasā ati  ayam ca hidam tesam bhikkhūnam antarākathā vippakatā hoti atha kho bhagavā sāyanhasamaya
translated: “It’s astounding and amazing, friends, how the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the Worthy One, rightly self-awakened, has said that mindfulness of the body, when developed and pursued, is of great fruit and great benefit.”

original: paṭisallānā vuṭṭhito yena upaṭṭhānasālā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
analyzed: paṭisallānā vuṭṭhitaḥ yena upaṭṭhāna sālā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi
translated: But this discussion of those monks was left unfinished. Then, in the evening, the Blessed One rose from his seclusion and went to the assembly hall, where he sat down on a seat made ready.

original: Nisajja kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
analyzed: nisajja kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: Seated, he addressed the monks:

original: “kāya nuttha, bhikkhave, etarahi kathāya sannisinnā, kā ca pana vo antarākathā vippakatā”ti?
analyzed: kāya nuttha bhikkhave etarahi kathāya sannisinnā kā ca pana vaḥ antarākathā vippakatā ati
translated: “What was the discussion that you were engaged in just now? What was the conversation that was underway?”

original: “Idha, bhante, amhākaṁ pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkantānaṁ upaṭṭhānasālāyaṁ sannisinnānaṁ sannipatitānaṁ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
analyzed: idha bhante amhākam pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkantānam upaṭṭhāna sālāyam sannisinnānam sannipatitānam ayam antarākathā udapādi
translated: “Just now, lord, after our meal, on returning from our alms round, we were sitting together in the assembly hall when this discussion arose:

original: ‘acchariyaṁ, āvuso, abbhutaṁ, āvuso.
analyzed: acchariyaḥ āvuso abbhutaḥ āvuso
translated: ‘It’s amazing, friends, it’s astounding,

original: Yāvañcidaṁ tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena kāyagatāsati bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā vuttā mahānisaṁsā’ti.
analyzed: yāvañcidam tena bhagavatā jānatā passatā arahatā sammāsambuddhena kāya gatā asati bhāvitā bahulīkatā mahapphalā vuttā mahā nisasā ati
translated: how the Blessed One, the Arahant, the Rightly Self-awakened One, has said that mindfulness of the body, when developed & pursued, is of great fruit, great benefit.’

original: Ayaṁ kho no, bhante, antarākathā vippakatā, atha bhagavā anuppatto”ti.
analyzed: ayam kho naḥ bhante antarākathā vippakatā atha bhagavā anuppatto ti
translated: This was our discussion, interrupted by the Blessed One’s arrival.”

original: “Kathaṁ bhāvitā ca, bhikkhave, kāyagatāsati kathaṁ bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahānisaṁsā?
analyzed: katham bhāvitā ca bhikkhave kāyagatā asati katham bahulīkatā mahapphalā hoti mahā nisasā
translated: “And how, monks, is mindfulness of the body developed & pursued so that it’s of great fruit, great benefit?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.🔽So satova assasati satova passasati;🔽dīghaṁ vā assasanto ‘dīghaṁ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, dīghaṁ vā passasanto ‘dīghaṁ passasāmī’ti pajānāti;
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu arañña gataḥ vā rukkha mūla gataḥ vā suññāgāra gataḥ vā nisīdati pallaṅkam ābhujitvā ujum kāyam paṇidhāya parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā  saḥ satas iva assasati satas iva passasati  dīgham vai assasantaḥ dīgham assasāmi iti pajānāti dīgham vā passasantaḥ dīgham passasāmi iti pajānāti
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu, gone to the forest or to the root of a tree or to an empty hut, sits down; having folded his legs crosswise, set his body erect, and established mindfulness in front of him,🔽breathing in long, he knows ‘I breathe in long’; or breathing out long, he knows ‘I breathe out long’;

original: rassaṁ vā assasanto ‘rassaṁ assasāmī’ti pajānāti, rassaṁ vā passasanto ‘rassaṁ passasāmī’ti pajānāti;🔽‘sabbakāyapaṭisaṁvedī assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘sabbakāyapaṭisaṁvedī passasissāmī’ti sikkhati;
analyzed: rassam vai assasantaḥ rassam assasāmi iti pajānāti rassam vā passasantaḥ rassam passasāmi iti pajānāti  sabba kāya paṭisavedī assasissāmi iti sikkhati sabba kāya paṭisavedī passasissāmi iti sikkhati
translated: or breathing in short, he knows ‘I breathe in short’; or breathing out short, he knows ‘I breathe out short’ -🔽experiencing the whole body I will breathe in, thus he trains himself; experiencing the whole body I will breathe out, thus he trains himself.

original: ‘passambhayaṁ kāyasaṅkhāraṁ assasissāmī’ti sikkhati, ‘passambhayaṁ kāyasaṅkhāraṁ passasissāmī’ti sikkhati.
analyzed: passambhayam kāya saṅkhāram assasissāmi iti sikkhati passambhayam kāya saṅkhāram passasissāmi iti sikkhati
translated: Calming the activity of the body I will breathe in, thus he trains himself; calming the activity of the body I will breathe out, thus he trains himself.

original: Tassa evaṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
analyzed: tassa evam appamattassa ātāpinaḥ pahitattassa viharataḥ ye gehasitā sara saṅkappā te pahīyanti
translated: As he abides thus diligent, ardent, and resolute, any memories and intentions related to the house-life are abandoned.

original: Tesaṁ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṁ santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
analyzed: tesam pahānā ajjhattam eva cittam santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati
translated: As he does so, his mind becomes steadied internally, quieted, brought to singleness, and concentrated.

original: Evaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāyagatāsatiṁ bhāveti.🔽Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu gacchanto vā ‘gacchāmī’ti pajānāti, ṭhito vā ‘ṭhitomhī’ti pajānāti, nisinno vā ‘nisinnomhī’ti pajānāti, sayāno vā ‘sayānomhī’ti pajānāti.🔽Yathā yathā vā panassa kāyo paṇihito hoti tathā tathā naṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: eva bhikkhave bhikkhu kāya gata asatim bhāveti  puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu gacchantaḥ vā gacchāmi iti pajānāti ṭhitaḥ vā ṭhitaḥ asmi iti pajānāti nisinnaḥ vā nisinnaḥ asmi iti pajānāti sa yānaḥ vā sa yānaḥ asmi iti pajānāti  yathā yathā vā panassa kāyaḥ paṇihitaḥ hoti tathā tathā nam pajānāti
translated: That is how a bhikkhu develops mindfulness of the body.🔽“Again, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu, when going forward or back, is one who acts with awareness; in looking straight on and in looking away, he is one who acts with awareness;

original: Tassa evaṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
analyzed: tassa evam appamattassa ātāpinaḥ pahitattassa viharataḥ ye gehasitā sara saṅkappā te pahīyanti
translated: in bending and in stretching, he is one who acts with awareness; in wearing robes and carrying outer robe and bowl, he is one who acts with awareness; in eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting, he is one who acts with awareness; in passing excrement and urine, he is one who acts with awareness; in walking, standing, sitting, falling asleep, waking up, talking, and remaining silent, he is one who acts with awareness.

original: Tesaṁ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṁ santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
analyzed: tesam pahānā ajjhattam eva cittam santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati
translated: As he does so, his mind becomes steadied internally, quieted, brought to singleness, and concentrated.

original: Evampi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāyagatāsatiṁ bhāveti.
analyzed: evam pi bhikkhave bhikkhu kāya gata asatim bhāveti
translated: That is how a bhikkhu develops mindfulness of the body.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajāna kārī hoti ālokite
translated: “Again, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu is one who acts with awareness in going forward and returning; in looking ahead and looking aside;🔽in bending and in stretching; in wearing robes and carrying outer robe and bowl; in eating, drinking, chewing, and tasting; in passing excrement and urine; in walking, standing, sitting, falling asleep, waking up, speaking, and remaining silent.

original: vilokite sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe🔽sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme
analyzed: vilokite sampajānakārī hoti samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti saṅghāṭi patta cīvara dhāraṇe  sampajāna kārī hoti asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajāna kārī hoti uccāra passāva kamme
translated: he is one who practises with clear awareness when looking ahead and when looking around, when drawing in and when extending the limbs, when wearing his robes and carrying his outer robe and bowl,🔽when eating, drinking, chewing his food, and tasting, when defecating and when urinating,

original: sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
analyzed: sampajāna kārī hoti gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajāna kārī hoti
translated: when walking, standing, sitting, sleeping, waking, talking, and keeping silent.

original: Tassa evaṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
analyzed: tassa evam appamattassa ātāpinaḥ pahitattassa viharataḥ ye gehasitā sara saṅkappā te pahīyanti
translated: As he abides diligent, ardent, and resolute, any memories and intentions related to the household life are abandoned,

original: Tesaṁ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṁ santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
analyzed: tesam pahānā ajjhattam eva cittam santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati
translated: and with the abandoning of them his mind becomes internally steady, settles down, becomes unified, and concentrated.

original: Evampi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāyagatāsatiṁ bhāveti.
analyzed: evam pi bhikkhave bhikkhu kāya gata asatim bhāveti
translated: It is in this way, bhikkhus, that a bhikkhu develops mindfulness directed to the body.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ uddhaṁ pādatalā adho kesamatthakā tacapariyantaṁ pūraṁ nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati:
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu imam eva kāyam uddham pāda talāḥ adhas kesamatthakā taca pariyantam pūram nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati
translated: “Again, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu reviews this very body up from the soles of the feet and down from the top of the hair and nape of the neck as full of many kinds of impurities: ‘There are in this body head-hairs, body-hairs, nails, teeth, skin, flesh, sinews, bones, bone-marrow, kidneys, heart, liver, pleura, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, contents of the stomach, feces, bile, phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovic fluid, urine.’

original: ‘atthi imasmiṁ kāye kesā lomā nakhā dantā taco maṁsaṁ nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjaṁ vakkaṁ
analyzed: atthi imasmin kāye kesāḥ lomā nakhāḥ dantāḥ tacaḥ masam nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjam vakka
translated: flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidney,

original: hadayaṁ yakanaṁ kilomakaṁ pihakaṁ papphāsaṁ antaṁ antaguṇaṁ udariyaṁ karīsaṁ pittaṁ
analyzed: hadayam yakanam kilomakam pihakam papphāsam antam antaguṇam udariyam karīsam pitta
translated: heart, liver, pleura, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, contents of the stomach, feces, bile,

analyzed: semham pubbaḥ lohitam sedaḥ medaḥ assu vasā kheḷaḥ siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttanti
translated: phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovic fluid, urine.’

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, ubhatomukhā putoḷi pūrā nānāvihitassa dhaññassa, seyyathidaṁ—
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave ubhatomukhā pūrā nānā vihitassa dhaññassa
translated: Just as though there were a bag open at both ends full of various kinds of grain,

original: sālīnaṁ vīhīnaṁ muggānaṁ māsānaṁ tilānaṁ taṇḍulānaṁ,
analyzed: sālīnam vīhīnam muggānam māsānam tilānam taṇḍulānam
translated: such as hill rice, white rice, mung beans, kidney beans, sesame seeds, chickpeas,

original: tamenaṁ cakkhumā puriso muñcitvā paccavekkheyya:
analyzed: tam enam cakkhumā purisaḥ muñcitvā paccavekkheyya
translated: and a man with good eyesight, pouring it out, were to reflect:

original: ‘ime sālī ime vīhī ime muggā ime māsā ime tilā ime taṇḍulā’ti;
analyzed: ime sālī ime vīhī ime muggāḥ ime māsāḥ ime tilāḥ ime
translated: ‘This is hill rice, this is white rice, these are mung beans, these are kidney beans, these are sesame seeds, these are chickpeas’;

analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave bhikkhu imam eva kāyam uddham pāda talāḥ adhas kesamatthakā taca pariyantam pūram nānappakārassa asucino paccavekkhati
translated: in the same way, a bhikkhu reflects on this very body from the soles of the feet on up, from the crown of the head on down, surrounded by skin and full of various kinds of unclean things:

analyzed: atthi imasmin kāye kesāḥ lomā nakhāḥ dantāḥ tacaḥ masam nhāru aṭṭhi aṭṭhimiñjam vakka
translated: flesh, sinews, bones, bone marrow, kidney,

analyzed: hadayam yakanam kilomakam pihakam papphāsam antam antaguṇam udariyam karīsam pitta
translated: heart, liver, pleura, spleen, lungs, intestines, mesentery, contents of the stomach, feces, bile,

original: semhaṁ pubbo lohitaṁ sedo medo assu vasā kheḷo siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttan’ti.
analyzed: semham pubbaḥ lohitam sedaḥ medaḥ assu vasā kheḷaḥ siṅghāṇikā lasikā muttanti
translated: phlegm, pus, blood, sweat, fat, tears, grease, saliva, snot, synovic fluid, urine.’

original: Tassa evaṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
analyzed: tassa evam appamattassa ātāpinaḥ pahitattassa viharataḥ ye gehasitā sara saṅkappā te pahīyanti
translated: As he remains thus heedful, ardent, & resolute, any memories & resolves related to the household life are abandoned.

original: Tesaṁ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṁ santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
analyzed: tesam pahānā ajjhattam eva cittam santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati
translated: With their abandoning, his mind becomes internally steady, settles down, becomes unified, & concentrated.

original: Evampi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāyagatāsatiṁ bhāveti.
analyzed: evam pi bhikkhave bhikkhu kāya gata asatim bhāveti
translated: That’s how a monk develops mindfulness immersed in the body.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ yathāṭhitaṁ yathāpaṇihitaṁ dhātuso paccavekkhati:
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu imam eva kāyam yathā ṭhitam yathā paṇihitam dhātuso paccavekkhati
translated: “Again, as if he were to see a corpse cast away in a charnel ground—one day, two days, three days dead—bloated, livid, & festering,

original: ‘atthi imasmiṁ kāye pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti.
analyzed: atthi imasmin kāye pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu uti
translated: he applies it to this very body, ‘This body, too: Such is its nature, such is its future, such its unavoidable fate.’

original: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, dakkho goghātako vā goghātakantevāsī vā gāviṁ vadhitvā catumahāpathe bilaso vibhajitvā nisinno assa;
analyzed: seyyathā api bhikkhave dakkhaḥ go ghātakaḥ vā go ghātaka antevāsī vā gāvim vadhitvā catu mahāpathe bilasaḥ vibhajitvā nisinnaḥ assa
translated: Just as if a skilled butcher or butcher’s apprentice, having slaughtered a cow, were sitting down at a crossroads with the carcass divided into portions,

original: evameva kho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ yathāṭhitaṁ yathāpaṇihitaṁ dhātuso paccavekkhati:
analyzed: evam eva kho bhikkhave bhikkhu imam eva kāyam yathā ṭhitam yathā paṇihitam dhātuso paccavekkhati
translated: in the same way, bhikkhus, a bhikkhu reviews this very body however placed, however disposed, as consisting of elements:

original: ‘atthi imasmiṁ kāye pathavīdhātu āpodhātu tejodhātu vāyodhātū’ti.
analyzed: atthi imasmin kāye pathavī dhātu āpaḥ dhātu tejaḥ dhātu vāyo dhātu uti
translated: ‘In this body there are the earth element, the water element, the fire element, and the air element.’

original: Tassa evaṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.
analyzed: tassa evam appamattassa ātāpinaḥ pahitattassa viharataḥ ye gehasitā sara saṅkappā te pahīyanti
translated: As he abides thus diligent, ardent, and resolute, any memories and intentions related to the house life are abandoned.

original: Tesaṁ pahānā ajjhattameva cittaṁ santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati.
analyzed: tesam pahānā ajjhattam eva cittam santiṭṭhati sannisīdati ekodi hoti samādhiyati
translated: With the abandoning of memories and intentions related to the house life, his mind becomes inwardly steady, settles down, and becomes unified and concentrated.

original: Evampi, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāyagatāsatiṁ bhāveti.
analyzed: evam pi bhikkhave bhikkhu kāya gata asatim bhāveti
translated: That is how a bhikkhu develops mindfulness directed to the body.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu seyyathāpi passeyya sarīraṁ sivathikāya chaḍḍitaṁ ekāhamataṁ vā dvīhamataṁ vā tīhamataṁ vā uddhumātakaṁ vinīlakaṁ vipubbakajātaṁ.
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave bhikkhu seyyathā api passeyya sarīram sivathikāya chaḍḍitam eka aha matam vā dvīha matam vā tīha matam vā uddhumātakam vinīlakam vipubbaka jāta
translated: Again, bhikkhus, as though he were to see a corpse thrown aside in a charnel ground, one, two, or three days dead, bloated, livid, and festering,

original: So imameva kāyaṁ upasaṁharati:
analyzed: saḥ imam eva kāyam upasaharati
translated: He then compares this very body with it thus:

original: ‘ayampi kho kāyo evaṁdhammo evaṁbhāvī evaṁanatīto’ti.
analyzed: ayam pi kho kāyaḥ eva dhammo eva bhāvī eva anatītaḥ ti
translated: ‘This body, too, is of the same nature, it will be like that, it is not exempt from that fate.’

original: Tassa evaṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato ye gehasitā sarasaṅkappā te pahīyanti.

translated: He understands a mind with lust as a mind with lust,🔽and a mind without lust as a mind without lust.

original: Sarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘sarāgaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,🔽vītarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ …pe…🔽sadosaṁ vā cittaṁ …🔽vītadosaṁ vā cittaṁ …
analyzed: sa rāgam vā cittam sa rāgam cittam iti pajānāti  vīta rāgam vā cittam pe  sa dosam vā cittam  vīta dosam vā cittam
translated: He understands a mind with hatred as a mind with hatred,🔽and a mind without hatred as a mind without hatred.🔽He understands a mind with delusion as a mind with delusion,

original: samohaṁ vā cittaṁ …🔽vītamohaṁ vā cittaṁ …
analyzed: sa moham vā cittam  vīta moham vā cittam
translated: and a mind without delusion as a mind without delusion.🔽He understands a contracted mind as contracted,

original: saṅkhittaṁ vā cittaṁ …🔽vikkhittaṁ vā cittaṁ …
analyzed: saṅkhittam vā cittam  vikkhittam vā cittam
translated: and a distracted mind as distracted.🔽He understands an exalted mind as exalted,

original: mahaggataṁ vā cittaṁ …🔽amahaggataṁ vā cittaṁ …
analyzed: mahaggatam vā cittam  a mahaggatam vā cittam
translated: and an unexalted mind as unexalted.🔽He understands a surpassed mind as surpassed,

original: sauttaraṁ vā cittaṁ …🔽anuttaraṁ vā cittaṁ …🔽samāhitaṁ vā cittaṁ …
analyzed: sauttaram vā cittam  anuttaram vā cittam  samāhitam vā cittam
translated: and an unsurpassed mind as unsurpassed.🔽He understands a concentrated mind as concentrated,

original: asamāhitaṁ vā cittaṁ …🔽vimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ …
analyzed: asamāhitam vā cittam  vimuttam vā cittam
translated: and an unconcentrated mind as unconcentrated.🔽He understands a liberated mind as liberated,

original: avimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘avimuttaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: a vimuttam vā cittam a vimuttam cittam iti pajānāti
translated: and an unliberated mind as unliberated.

original: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
analyzed: so aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati sa iyyathida ekam pi jātim dve pi jātiyaḥ pe iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati
translated: He remembers various past lives, with their aspects and particulars.

original: Dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
analyzed: dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti
translated: With the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, he sees beings passing away and being reborn, inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate, and he understands how beings fare in accordance with their kamma.

original: Āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: āsavānam khayā anāsavam cetaḥ vimuttim paññā vimuttim diṭṭhe iva dhamme sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharati
translated: By realising for himself with direct knowledge, he here and now enters upon and abides in the deliverance of mind and deliverance by wisdom that are taintless with the destruction of the taints.

original: Kāyagatāya, bhikkhave, satiyā āsevitāya bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya susamāraddhāya ime dasānisaṁsā pāṭikaṅkhā”ti.
analyzed: kāyagatāya bhikkhave satiyā āsevitāya bhāvitāya bahulīkatāya yānīkatāya vatthukatāya anuṭṭhitāya paricitāya su samāraddhāya ime dasa anisasā pāṭikaṅkhāti
translated: When mindfulness of the body has been repeatedly practised, developed, cultivated, used as a vehicle, used as a basis, established, consolidated, and well undertaken, these ten benefits may be expected.”

original: Idamavoca bhagavā.
analyzed: idam avoca bhagavān
translated: That is what the Blessed One said.

original: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.
analyzed: attamanāḥ te bhikkhū bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinandunti
translated: The bhikkhus were satisfied and delighted in the Blessed One’s words.

original: Kāyagatāsatisuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ navamaṁ.
analyzed: kāyagata asati suttam niṭṭhitam navama
translated: The ninth sutta in the Long Division.
